title: Gustáv Papp
text:
Gustáv Papp (28 September 1919 – 7 October 1997) was a Slovak <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="tenor">tenor</a> who had an active international career during the 1940s through the 1980s. He was notably a leading artist at the <a href="Slovak%20National%20Theatre">Slovak National Theatre</a> in <a href="Bratislava">Bratislava</a> from 1948 through 1987. He made a number of recordings made on the <a href="Supraphon">Supraphon</a> label and also worked for many years as a medical doctor.
Biography.
Born in <a href="%C4%8Cierny%20Balog">Čierny Balog</a>, Papp studied medicine at the <a href="University%20of%20Bratislava">University of Bratislava</a> and passed his medical exams, becoming a Doctor of Medicine in 1944. For many years he worked as a doctor in addition to performing. While specializing in <a href="general%20surgery">general surgery</a> he became increasingly interested in opera and eventually entered the <a href="Bratislava%20Conservatory">Bratislava Conservatory</a> in 1940 where he studied singing with D. Žuravlevová through 1947. He later pursued further studies at the <a href="University%20of%20Music%20and%20Performing%20Arts%2C%20Vienna">Vienna Music Academy</a>.
Papp made his professional opera decut in 1948 at the <a href="Slovak%20National%20Theatre">Slovak National Theatre</a> (SNT) as Don José in <a href="Georges%20Bizet">Georges Bizet</a>'s "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>". He returned frequently to the theatre through 1955 as a guest artist and then was a member at the house from 1955 through 1987. His extensive stage repertoire at the SNT encompassed mainly heroic tenor roles from the Italian and German repertories and a total of 21 Slovak opera roles. He notably created roles in the world premieres of several operas by composer <a href="J%C3%A1n%20Cikker">Ján Cikker</a>, including the title roles in "Juro Jánošík" (1954) and "Beg Bajazid" (1957) and parts in "Vzkriesenie" (1962) and "Zo života hmyzu" (1987). Some of his other stage roles included Básnik in <a href="Peter%20Zvon">Peter Zvon</a>'s "Tanec nad plačom", Ondrej Zimoň in <a href="Eugen%20Sucho%C5%88">Eugen Suchoň</a>'s "<a href="Kr%C3%BAt%C5%88ava">Krútňava</a>", Prince Vasiliy Ivanovich Shuysky in <a href="Modest%20Mussorgsky">Modest Mussorgsky</a>'s "<a href="Boris%20Godunov%20%28opera%29">Boris Godunov</a>", and the title role <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="Otello">Otello</a>".
On the international stage Papp was a member at the opera house in <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a>, Germany from 1960 to 1966. He also portrayed a number <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Wagnerian</a> heroes as a guest artist at the <a href="Semperoper">Semperoper</a> in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a>. He was highly esteemed concert singer and gave successful concert tours throughout <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>, <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, and <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. In 1966, he was awarded the <a href="USSR%20State%20Prize">USSR State Prize</a> and in 1968 he was named a <a href="Meritorious%20Artist">Meritorious Artist</a>. In 1991 he was decorated with the <a href="Order%20of%20Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Garrigue%20Masaryk">Order of Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk</a> by the State of Czechoslovakia.
After his retirement from the stage in 1987, Papp worked as a voice teacher in Bratislava for many years. He was married to Eva Pappová. He died in Bratislava.
